awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Roadmap to Commercialization of City-Climber Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
This Innovation Corps project proposes to test the commercial feasibility of a wall-climbing robot system based on the teams "City-Climber" technology for building façade inspection and glass wall cleaning applications. The current practice of manual inspection of building façade is time-consuming, expensive, and poses risk to human workers. The City-Climber technology provides a solution to meet a strong demand for automated inspection of building façades. In addition, the City-Climber robots can be modified to carry out tasks such as to clean glass walls and solar panels.  Under prior funding, this team developed several wall-climbing robot prototypes, named City-Climber. 

Unlike traditional climbing robots that rely on magnetic devices and vacuum suction techniques and some recent novel climbing robots such as vortex climber and the robots using micro-spine inspired by the gecko foot, the City-Climber robots use an aerodynamic rotor package which achieves a balance between strong adhesion force and high mobility. If successfully commercialized, City-Climber robots have many potential applications such as: 1) inspection of building facades for cracks or other defects; 2) inspection of concrete structures such as power plant tower, dam, bridges, etc.; 3) cleaning of glass panels of high-rise buildings, 4) cleaning of solar panels; 5) inspection/spray painting/blasting of storage tanks, aircraft, ship hulls, billboards, etc.; 6) surveillance of tunnels or danger zones where ground access in not available.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this I-Corps project is to study the commercialization feasibility of the wall-climbing robots named as City-Climbers.  The City-Climber I-Corps team attended three learning/exercise workshops about entrepreneurship at Stanford University led by Steven Blank. Then the team participated in eight weekly webinars to learn the basics of entrepreneurship and customer discovery. At the end of the eight weeks, the team returned to Stanford University to present their business model canvas and give a final pitch to venture capitalists. During the 3-month customer discovery journey, the team contacted more than 100 potential customers, collaborators, industry experts, NYC building inspection regulators, manufacture partners, competitors, and gained much better understanding of the market opportunities of the City-Climber robots. In addition, this project support an in-house design team of CCNY senior undergraduate students who have successfully developed a minimum viable product (MVP) and produced a video to demonstrate the capability of the wall-climbing robot for commercialization. 

The team found out that the wall-climbing robots can be used for non-destructive inspection of “big, flat things” such as building façade, tunnels, bridges, dams, nuclear cooling towers, and chemical storage tanks. The broader impact/commercial potential of wall-climbing robots is that it allows inspections of human-built infrastructure to be performed significantly faster and more thorough at a lower cost by eliminating the use of scaffolds, thus saving time & money, improving safety of human operators and making the national civil infrastructure more secure. New York City and many other cities in the world have laws that mandate the facade inspection of high-rise buildings ?every 5 years. The aging infrastructure and residential apartments also have strong needs for inspection and property maintenance. Considering the number of buildings in NYC to be inspected every ?year, and over millions of buildings, bridges and tunnels in USA and around the world that require continuous maintenances and inspection, the market of the wall-climbing robots ?is vast.

The team made a clear “Go” decision for NSF I-Corps project since we have validated that there is a scalable market in building inspection and NDT sectors using wall-climbing robots. The team anticipates a paradigm shift from manual inspection to automated inspection using wall-climbing robots and is determined to further develop the technology and pursue commercialization opportunities to transfer the laboratory innovation to the products to satisfy the demands and to create jobs.
